actions-list.actionItem: The House adjourned pursuant to a previous special order. The next meeting is scheduled for 9:00 a.m. on November 8, 2023.
On motion to adjourn Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. Burchett moved that the House do now adjourn.
The House proceeded with further one minute speeches.
Mr. Wilson (SC) asked unanimous consent that when the House adjourns today, it adjourn to meet at 9:00 a.m. on November 8. Agreed to without objection.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 234
actions-list.actionItem: 188, 4 Present (Roll no. 622).

Considered as unfinished business. H. Res. 845 — "Censuring Representative Rashida Tlaib for promoting false narratives regarding the October 7, 2023, Hamas attack on Israel and for calling for the destruction of the state of Israel."
The Chair announced that the unfinished business was the question on agreeing to H. Res. 845, which had been debated earlier and on which further proceedings had been postponed.
Pursuant to clause 1(c) of rule XIX, the Chair announced further proceedings on H.R. 4820 would be postponed.
The previous question was ordered pursuant to the rule.
The House rose from the Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union to report H.R. 4820.

actions-list.header: On agreeing to the Self amendment; Failed by recorded vote: 211
On agreeing to the Santos amendment; Failed by recorded vote: 112
On agreeing to the Norman amendment; Failed by recorded vote: 212
On agreeing to the Norman amendment; Failed by recorded vote: 155
On agreeing to the Norman amendment; Failed by recorded vote: 164
On agreeing to the Massie amendment; Failed by recorded vote: 201
On agreeing to the Massie amendment; Failed by recorded vote: 211
On agreeing to the Hageman amendment; Failed by recorded vote: 191
On agreeing to the Schweikert amendment; Failed by recorded vote: 104
On agreeing to the Schweikert amendment; Failed by recorded vote: 133
On agreeing to the Grothman amendment; Failed by recorded vote: 106
On agreeing to the Blunt Rochester amendment; Agreed to by recorded vote: 238
On agreeing to the Davidson amendment; Failed by recorded vote: 144

actions-list.actionItem: The House resolved into Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union for further consideration.

Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 4820 — "Making appropriations for the Departments of Transportation, and Housing and Urban Development, and related agencies for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2024, and for other purposes."
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of November 7.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is subject to the call of the Chair.

actions-list.header: The Speaker laid before the House a message from the President transmitting a notification that the National Emergency with respect to Iran that was declared in Executive Order 12170 of November 14, 1979, is to continue in effect beyond November 14, 2023.
actions-list.actionItem: referred to the Committee on Foreign Affairs and ordered to be printed (H. Doc. 118-79).

actions-list.header: Board of Visitors to the United States Naval Academy
actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to 10 U.S.C. 8468(a), and the order of the House of January 9, 2023, the Speaker appointed the following member of the House to the Board of Visitors to the United States Naval Academy: Mr. Deluzio.

actions-list.header: Board of Visitors to the United States Military Academy
actions-list.actionItem: Pursuant to 10 U.S.C. 7455(a), and the order of the House of January 9, 2023, the Speaker appointed the following member of the House to the Board of Visitors to the United States Military Academy: Mr. Bishop of Georgia.

Board of Trustees of the American Folklife Center in the Library of Congress- Pursuant to 20 U.S.C. 2103(b), and the order of the House of January 9, 2023, the Speaker appointed Ms. Amy Kitchener, Fresno, California- 6 year term.
Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union rises leaving H.R. 4820 as unfinished business.
On motion that the committee rise Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. Cole moved that the committee rise.

At the conclusion of debate on the Self amendment No. 74, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Quigley demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Self amendment No. 74.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Self,  numbered 74 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to prohibit funds from being used towards implementing, administering, or enforcing the Equity Action Plan of the Department of Housing and Urban Development established pursuant to Executive Order 13985 entitled "Advancing Racial Equity and Support for Underserved Communities Through the Federal Government."

At the conclusion of debate on the Santos amendment No. 73, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Quigley demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Santos amendment No. 73.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Santos,  numbered 73 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to reduce the salary of Polly Trottenberg, Deputy Secretary of Transportation, to $1.
On agreeing to the Roy amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Roy amendment No. 72.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Roy,  numbered 72 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to prohibit funds from being used to implement any of the Administration's executive orders on climate change.
On agreeing to the Perry amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Perry amendment No. 71.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Perry,  numbered 71 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to prohibit the use of funds to finalize, implement, or enforce the notice of proposed rulemaking related to Automatic Emergency Braking.
On agreeing to the Perry amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Perry amendment No. 70.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Perry,  numbered 70 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to prohibit the use of any funds for transit-oriented development.
On agreeing to the Norman amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Norman amendment No. 69.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Norman,  numbered 69 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to prohibit funds to finalize, implement, or enforce the rule titled "Corporate Average Fuel Economy Standards for Passenger Cars and Light Trucks for Model Years 2027-2032 and Fuel Efficiency Standards for Heavy-Duty Pickup Trucks and Vans for Model Years 2030-2035."
On agreeing to the Norman amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Norman amendment No. 68.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Norman,  numbered 68 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to prohibit funds for air travel by the Secretary of Transportation other than in economy class on a commercial flight.
On agreeing to the Norman amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Norman amendment No. 67.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Norman,  numbered 67 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to prohibit funds from being used to purchase or lease a vehicle for use by the Secretary of Transportation.

At the conclusion of debate on the Norman amendment No. 66, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Quigley demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Norman amendment No. 66.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Norman,  numbered 66 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to prohibit funding for the implementation of the rule entitled "Equal Access in Accordance With an Individual's Gender Identity in Community Planning and Development Programs".
On agreeing to the Norman amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Norman amendment No. 65.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Norman,  numbered 65 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to prohibit the use of funds for the consideration of the Social Cost of Greenhouse Gases (SC-GHG) in the development and implementation of budgets, federal procurement processes, or environmental reviews.

At the conclusion of debate on the Norman amendment No. 64, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Quigley demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Norman amendment No. 64.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Norman,  numbered 64 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to reduce the salary of Julia Gordon, Assistant Secretary for Housing and the Federal Housing Commissioner, to $1.
On agreeing to the Norman amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Norman amendment No. 63.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Norman,  numbered 63 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to prohibit funds made available by this Act for the Federal Transit Administration's Electric or Low-Emitting Ferry Pilot Program.

At the conclusion of debate on the Norman amendment No. 62, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Quigley demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Norman amendment No. 62.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Norman,  numbered 62 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to reduce the salary of Ann E. Carlson, Acting Administrator of the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, to $1.
On agreeing to the McCormick amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the McCormick amendment No. 61.

An amendment, offered by Mr. McCormick,  numbered 61 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to prohibit funds from implementing Executive Orders 14037 of August 5, 2021 (86 Fed. Reg. 43583; relating to strengthening American leadership in clean cars and trucks), Executive Order 14057 of December 8, 2021 (86 Fed. Reg. 70935; relating to catalyzing clean energy industries and jobs through Federal sustainability), or Executive Order 14096 of April 21, 2023 (88 Fed. Reg. 25251; relating to revitalizing our Nations commitment to environmental justice for all).

At the conclusion of debate on the Massie amendment No. 60, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Quigley demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Massie amendment No. 60.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Massie,  numbered 60 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to prohibit funds from being used to implement Sec. 24220 of the IIJA, which mandates that new vehicles include a kill switch to monitor diver performance and prevent vehicle operation.

At the conclusion of debate on the Massie amendment No. 59, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Quigley demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Massie amendment No. 59.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Massie,  numbered 59 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to prohibit any funds from being used to conduct a competition analysis of mergers.
On agreeing to the Hageman amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Hageman amendment No. 58.
An amendment, offered by Ms. Hageman,  numbered 58 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to prohibit the Department of Transportation from using funds for remote work agreements.

At the conclusion of debate on the Hageman amendment No. 57, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Quigley demanded a recorded vote and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Hageman amendment No. 57.

An amendment, offered by Ms. Hageman,  numbered 57 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to prohibit funds made available by this act from being used for the National Electric Vehicle Infrastructure Formula Program.
On agreeing to the Greene (GA) amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Green (GA) amendment No. 56.
An amendment, offered by Ms. Greene (GA),  numbered 56 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to prohibit funding for the Department of Transportation's Climate Change Center.
On agreeing to the Greene (GA) amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Greene (GA) amendment No. 54.
An amendment, offered by Ms. Greene (GA),  numbered 54 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to reduce the salary of Transportation Secretary Pete Buttigieg to $1.
On agreeing to the Graves (LA) amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Graves amendment No. 53.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Graves (LA),  numbered 53 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to prohibit funds to promulgate new major rules if the Office of Management and Budget determines that the regulation is likely to result in a significant impact on the economy, a major increase in prices for consumers, or adverse effects on American global competition.
On agreeing to the Gooden (TX) amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Gooden (TX) amendment No. 52.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Gooden (TX),  numbered 52 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to prohibit the Department of Transportation from contributing funds to the National Highway and Traffic Safety Administration to enforce any rules or regulation in relation to center high-mounted stop lamps, a type of rear brake light.
On agreeing to the Fry amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Fry amendment No. 50.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Fry,  numbered 50 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to prohibit funds to implement, administer, or enforce any Federal law, rule, or regulation that would require an individual to wear a mask on public transportation conveyances and at transportation hubs.
On agreeing to the Cammack amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Cammack amendment No. 49.

An amendment, offered by Mrs. Cammack,  numbered 49 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to prohibit funds from being used to finalize any rule or regulation that has resulted in or is likely to result in an annual effect on the economy of $100 million or more.
On agreeing to the Burlison amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Burlison amendment No. 48.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Burlison,  numbered 48 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to prohibit funds to the Charging and Fueling Infrastructure Discretionary Grant Program.

At the conclusion of debate on the Schweikert amendment No. 47, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Quigley demanded a recorded vote, and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Schweikert amendment No. 47.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Schweikert,  numbered 47 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to reduce by, 57 percent, each amount of discretionary budget authority provided by the bill.

At the conclusion of debate on the Schweikert amendment No. 46, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Quigley demanded a recorded vote, and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Schweikert amendment No. 46.
An amendment, offered by Mr. Schweikert,  numbered 46 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to reduce total funding to match FY 19 levels.
On agreeing to the Hageman amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Hageman amendment No. 43.

An amendment, offered by Ms. Hageman,  numbered 43 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to prohibit remote work agreements for HUD employees when the alternative worksite is located within a 50 mile radius of a HUD office.

At the conclusion of debate on the Grothman amendment No. 37, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Quigley demanded a recorded vote, and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Grothman amendment No. 37.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Grothman,  numbered 37 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to increase and decreases funding for the Community Development Fund to promote the identification and removal of barriers to affordable housing production and preservation.

At the conclusion of debate on the Blunt Rochester amendment No. 36, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced the nays had prevailed. Ms. Blunt Rochester demanded a recorded vote, and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Blunt Rochester amendment No. 36.

An amendment, offered by Ms. Blunt Rochester,  numbered 36 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to increase and decreases funding for the Community Development Fund to promote the identification and removal of barriers to affordable housing production and preservation.

At the conclusion of debate on the Davidson amendment No. 34, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the amendment and by voice vote, announced the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Quigley demanded a recorded vote, and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Davidson amendment No. 34.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Davidson,  numbered 34 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to decrease funding for the Housing Opportunities for Persons With AIDS program by $505 million dollars and transfer the savings to Spending Reduction Account.
On agreeing to the Grothman amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Grothman amendment No. 32.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Grothman,  numbered 32 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to increase and decrease funding by $1 million for the section 8 housing program budget to highlight the need for a GAO study on marriage penalties within the program.
On agreeing to the Strong amendment; Agreed to by voice vote.
Pursuant to the provisions of H. Res. 838, the Committee of the Whole proceeded with 10 minutes of debate on the Strong amendment No. 31.

An amendment, offered by Mr. Strong,  numbered 31 printed in Part B of House Report 118-261 to increase and decrease funding by $1 million for tenant-based rental assistance to express support for Public Housing Authorities to conduct drug testing as a condition of public housing benefits.
The House resolved into Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union for further consideration.

Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 4820 — "Making appropriations for the Departments of Transportation, and Housing and Urban Development, and related agencies for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2024, and for other purposes."

At the conclusion of debate on H. Res. 845, the Chair put the question on agreeing to the resolution and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Mr. Raskin demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The previous question was ordered without objection.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 845.
Motion to reconsider laid on the table. Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On motion to table the measure Failed by the Yeas and Nays: 208
actions-list.actionItem: 213, 1 Present (Roll no. 608).
Ms. Clark (MA) moved to table the measure.

Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 845 — "Censuring Representative Rashida Tlaib for promoting false narratives regarding the October 7, 2023, Hamas attack on Israel and for calling for the destruction of the state of Israel."

actions-list.header: QUESTION OF THE PRIVILEGES OF THE HOUSE
actions-list.actionItem: Mr. McCormick rose to a question of the privileges of the House and offered the resolution. The Chair directed the Clerk to report the resolution. Upon examination of the resolution, the Chair determined that the resolution did constitute a question of the privileges of the House.
Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union rises leaving H.R. 4820 as unfinished business.
On motion that the committee rise Agreed to by voice vote.
Mr. Cole moved that the committee rise.

actions-list.header: On agreeing to the Brecheen amendment; Failed by recorded vote: 174
On agreeing to the Grothman amendment; Agreed to by recorded vote: 213
On agreeing to the Perry amendment; Failed by recorded vote: 148
On agreeing to the Perry amendment; Failed by recorded vote: 125
On agreeing to the Escobar amendment; Failed by recorded vote: 212

actions-list.actionItem: The Chair announced that the unfinished business was the question on agreeing to amendments to H.R. 4820, which had been debated earlier and on which further proceedings had been postponed.
The House resolved into Committee of the Whole House on the state of the Union for further consideration.

Considered as unfinished business. H.R. 4820 — "Making appropriations for the Departments of Transportation, and Housing and Urban Development, and related agencies for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2024, and for other purposes."
Motion to reconsider laid on the table Agreed to without objection.

actions-list.header: On agreeing to the resolution Agreed to by recorded vote: 217
On ordering the previous question Agreed to by the Yeas and Nays: 217

actions-list.actionItem: Considered as unfinished business. H. Res. 847 — "Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 4664) making appropriations for financial services and general government for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2024, and for other purposes."
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of November 7.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess for a period of less than 15 minutes.

At the conclusion of debate on H. Res. 847, the Chair put the question on ordering the previous question and by voice vote, announced that the ayes had prevailed. Ms. Leger Fernandez demanded the yeas and nays and the Chair postponed further proceedings until a time to be announced.
The House proceeded with one hour of debate on H. Res. 847.

Considered as privileged matter. H. Res. 847 — "Providing for consideration of the bill (H.R. 4664) making appropriations for financial services and general government for the fiscal year ending September 30, 2024, and for other purposes."
The House proceeded with one minute speeches, which by direction of the Chair would be limited to 15 per side of the aisle.
The Chair designated Mr. Harder of CA to lead the Members in reciting the Pledge of Allegiance to the Flag.
The Speaker announced approval of the Journal.  Pursuant to clause 1, rule I, the Journal stands approved.
Today's prayer was offered by the House Chaplain, Chaplain Margaret Grun Kibben.
The House convened, returning from a recess continuing the legislative day of November 7.
The Speaker announced that the House do now recess. The next meeting is scheduled for 12:00 P.M. today.
The House proceeded with Morning-Hour Debate. At the conclusion of Morning-Hour, the House will recess until 12:00 p.m. for the start of legislative business.
The Speaker designated the Honorable Dale W. Strong to act as Speaker pro tempore for today.
The House convened, starting a new legislative day.
